review.title: Properties of Bayesian Belief Network Learning Algorithms
review.abstract: bayesian empirical belief in network learning classification algorithms naturally have three basic systematic components : initially a measure algorithm of locating a distributed network structure and a database, a functional search heuristic that desperately chooses small network component structures to be considered, and such a method efficient of estimating among the probability tables emerged from defining the similarity database. now this paper contributes to all these concepts three additional topics. the behavior statistics of the algorithm bayesian goodness measure of its cooper and herskovits complexity and is a minimum description length ( mdl ) measure are compared routinely with respect value to their actual properties for both its limiting size and finite allocation size databases. importantly it is shown that the mdl measure has more commonly desirable properties than the bayesian measure calculated when a spatial distribution is planned to be learned. ultimately it specifically is shown that eagerly selecting belief networks with certain minimallity of properties is np - hard. this aforementioned result justifies the use behavior of search heuristics naive instead of exact algorithms for actively choosing whole network structures to be formally considered. in some example cases, averaging a collection theory of concurrent belief networks can can be better represented by a single belief network which therefore leads gradually to a supposedly new kind of probability representation table estimation called population smoothing. we argue that rational smoothing can be efficiently best implemented by incorporating it in the search heuristic. many experimental results instead suggest strongly that improving for continuous learning probabilities of belief networks smoothing is proving helpful.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper the behavior of various be­ lief network learning algorithms is stud­ ied. Selecting belief networks with cer­ tain minimallity properties turns out to be NP-hard, which justifies the use of search heuristics. Search heuristics based on the Bayesian measure of Cooper and Her­ skovits and a minimum description length (MDL) measure are compared with re­ spect to their properties for both limit­ ing and finite database sizes. It is shown that the MDL measure has more desir­ able properties than the Bayesian mea­ sure. Experimental results suggest that for learning probabilities of belief net­ works smoothing is helpful.
